values.description:
Add 4 scripts:

* create server-side VPN keys
* create client-side VPN keys
* bundle server-side VPN keys
* bundle client-side VPN keys

Also update docs to explain how to use them.
values.title: Add scripts for key generation and bundling

summary.raw:
Add 4 scripts:

* create server-side VPN keys
* create client-side VPN keys
* bundle server-side VPN keys
* bundle client-side VPN keys

Also update docs to explain how to use them.
summary.html:
Add 4 scripts:

  • create server-side VPN keys
  • create client-side VPN keys
  • bundle server-side VPN keys
  • bundle client-side VPN keys

Also update docs to explain how to use them.

values.description:
3 routes:

POST: `/tap/sasc/key`: generate server keys

GET: `/tap/sasc/server/:resourceId`: download server keys

GET: `/tap/sasc/client/:resourceId`: download client keys

The server and client key tarbombs are saved to `keys/servername`
values.title: Set up routes for creating and serving vpn keys

summary.raw:
3 routes:

POST: `/tap/sasc/key`: generate server keys

GET: `/tap/sasc/server/:resourceId`: download server keys

GET: `/tap/sasc/client/:resourceId`: download client keys

The server and client key tarbombs are saved to `keys/servername`
summary.html:
3 routes:

POST: /tap/sasc/key: generate server keys

GET: /tap/sasc/server/:resourceId: download server keys

GET: /tap/sasc/client/:resourceId: download client keys

The server and client key tarbombs are saved to keys/servername

values.description:
I'm assuming that `cloudsim-options.json` will have this kind of content for a payload:
~~~
{
  "token": "<redacted>",
  "role" : "payload",
  "client_route" : "https://devkeys.cloudsim.io/tap/sasc/client/vpn-003",
  "server_ip" : "111.222.3.4",
  "client_id" : "myClient2"
}
~~~

and this kind of content for an arbiter:
~~~
{
  "token": "<redacted>",
  "role" : "arbiter",
  "blue_route" : "https://devkeys.cloudsim.io/tap/sasc/server/vpn-003",
  "gold_route" : "https://devkeys.cloudsim.io/tap/sasc/server/vpn-004",
  "blue_subnet" : "192.168.2",
  "gold_subnet" : "192.168.3"
}
~~~
values.title: Add deploy scripts

{

values.description: With this change a client named `payload` will always get the address `<subnet>.10` from the VPN server.
values.title: Static ip for payload

summary.raw: With this change a client named `payload` will always get the address `<subnet>.10` from the VPN server.
summary.html: With this change a client named payload will always get the address <subnet>.10 from the VPN server.

values.description:
Mainly for speeding up server key generation.

After a little bit of research online, I found that there are people who oppose reusing dh2048.pem files while others say it's perfectly fine. So I ended up trying out this solution that suggests generating DSA-like DH paramters:

http://security.stackexchange.com/questions/95178/diffie-hellman-parameters-still-calculating-after-24-hours

key generation is now fast on my machine, <1sec
values.title: Generate DSA-like DH parameter

summary.raw:

http://security.stackexchange.com/questions/95178/diffie-hellman-parameters-still-calculating-after-24-hours

key generation is now fast on my machine, <1sec
summary.html:
Mainly for speeding up server key generation.

After a little bit of research online, I found that there are people who oppose reusing dh2048.pem files while others say it's perfectly fine. So I ended up trying out this solution that suggests generating DSA-like DH paramters:

http://security.stackexchange.com/questions/95178/diffie-hellman-parameters-still-calculating-after-24-hours

key generation is now fast on my machine, <1sec

values.description:
This routing is required to allow the arbiter to set its `ROS_HOSTNAME` to one value (e.g., 192.168.2.1), but be reachable by clients on both VPNs.

This should *not* be merged until the corresponding change is made in `cloudsim-sim` to update the `sasc_deploy.bash` script to pass the new argument.
values.title: add route to reach the server IP of the other subnet

summary.raw:
This routing is required to allow the arbiter to set its `ROS_HOSTNAME` to one value (e.g., 192.168.2.1), but be reachable by clients on both VPNs.

This should *not* be merged until the corresponding change is made in `cloudsim-sim` to update the `sasc_deploy.bash` script to pass the new argument.
summary.html:
This routing is required to allow the arbiter to set its ROS_HOSTNAME to one value (e.g., 192.168.2.1), but be reachable by clients on both VPNs.

This should not be merged until the corresponding change is made in cloudsim-sim to update the sasc_deploy.bash script to pass the new argument.

values.description:
This is the same as pull request #10, but for the production server.

That pull request worked fine for the permission routes and *almost* right for the sasc routes. I'll merge it into the production server too in order to use the permission routes.
